text:
MASS VOLUME RELATIONSHIP

Limiting reactants determines the reaction. 

No of Mole = 

This means that to calculate the number of moles in a chemical substance, you divide the general mass of the substance by the molar mass. E.g. oxygen gas, the molar mass of O2 = 16 + 16 = 32g/mol. Let’s take for instance that the giving mass (reacting mass) is 320g. Then the number of moles is 320/32= 10 moles of O2.

Molarity in mol/dm3 = 

Molarity can also be referred to as the concentration. It compares the number of moles as given above to the volume.

Let’s assume that the 10 moles of oxygen gas were in a cylinder of volume 1000dm3

Then, the concentration is given by   = 10moles of O2 /1000dm3 = 0.01mol/dm3. 

 

Molar volume of a gas = 22.4dm3 = 22400cm3 at STP.

This means that every 1(one) mole of a gas has a fixed volume that is equal to = 22.4dm3, at STP.

One mole of oxygen (O2) = 22.4dm3 = 22400cm3.

Every 32g/mol of O2 will occupy a volume of 22.4dm3 = 22400cm3. 

 32g/mol of O2 = 22.4dm3

This is all you need to know, let’s start applying it.

How many moles of oxygen are present in 16g of oxygen gas.

We first write formular O2 

Recall, No of Mole = 

Reacting mass = 16g

Molar mass = 16g/mol + 16g/mol = 32g/mol

No of moles = 16/32 = 0.5 moles of O2.

 

Example

Calc. the mass of sodium trioxocarbonate (iv) solution produced by the complete decomposition of 16.8g of sodium hydrogen trioxocarbonate (iv). (H = 1, O = 16, Na = 23, S = 32).

Solution

We first write the balanced equation of reaction

2NaHCO3   Na2CO3 + CO2 + H2O 

We want to know the mass of Na2CO3 that was produced from NaHCO3, we need their molar mass first.

Molar mass of NaHCO3 = 23 + 1 + 12 + (3  16) = 84g/mol

Molar mass of Na2CO3 = (23   2) + 12 + (3  16) = 106g/mol

From the equation

2 moles of NaHCO3 produced 1 mole of Na2CO3

Therefore, 

2  84g/mol NaHCO3= 106g/mol of Na2CO3

168g/mol NaHCO3 = 106g/mol of Na2CO3

Since we know that it takes 168g/mol NaHCO3 to produce 106g/mol of Na2CO3, we can therefore determine how many Na2CO3 that will be produced by 16.8g/mol of NaHCO3.

168 = 106

1.68 = x

Cross multiply

x ×168 = 1.68 ×106

x =  = 10.35g/mol

therefore, 10.35g/mol of Na2CO3 was produced by 16.8g/mol of NaHCO3.

Hope you get!!!

 

Example

A solution of NaOH containing 6.0 g in 250 cm3 of solution has a concentration of

A. 0.04 moldm-3 B. 0.15 moldm-3 C. 0.60 moldm-3 D. 0.96 moldm-3

(2012/2013 no 5). C

Since,

6.0g of NaOH = 250Cm3

Xg of NaOH = 1000Cm3

Cross multiply

X =  = 24g/dm3

Molar mass of NaOH = 23 + 1 + 16 = 40g/dm3

Conc. of NaOH = 24/40 = 0.6mol/dm3

Example

The decomposition of hydrogen peroxide is represented by the equation 2H2O2(g)  2H2O + O2(g).

What mass of hydrogen peroxide would be required to produce 22.4dm3 of oxygen at STP.

Solution 

Molar volume of a gas = 22.4dm3

From the equation

2moles of Hydrogen peroxide produced 2moles of water and one mole of Oxygen gas

2H2O2(g)  2H2O + O2(g).

2  : 2 : 1

Molar mass of H2O2 = (1  2) + (16   2) = 34mol/dm3.

Since its 2 moles

2  34mol/dm3 of H2O2  22.4dm3 of oxygen

22.4dm3.

Example

A solution of NaOH containing 6.0 g in 250 cm3 of solution has a concentration of

A. 0.04 moldm-3, B. 0.15 moldm-3, C. 0 .60 moldm-3, D. 0.96 moldm-3

C (2013/2014, no. 5)

6.0g of NaOH = 250Cm3

Xg of NaOH = 1000Cm3

X =  = 24g/dm3

Example

A solution of calcium bromide contains 20g/dm3. What is the molar concentration of calcium bromide relative to bromide ions? [Ca =40, Br= 80]

A. 0.1, 0.1, B. 0.1, 0.2, C. 0.1, 0.05, D. 0.05, 0.1

C (2014/2015, no. 3)

Molar Conc. = 

Molar mass of CaBr2 = 40 + (80 x 2) = 200g/mol 

Molar Conc. =  = 0.1mol/dm3

The concentration of CaBr2 can be calculated by adding the concentration of Ca2+ and Br2- since they are equivalent.

0.1 = x + x = 2x

0.1 = 2x

X = 0.1/2 = 0.05

5. The burning of phosphorus in excess oxygen is represented by the equation

P4 + 5O2→ P4O10

Example

What is the volume of oxygen at STP required for the complete oxidation of 18.6g of phosphorus? [P=31, O=16, Molar Volume of a gas at STP=22.4 dm at STP=22.4 dm3]

A. 5.6 dm3, B. 11.2 dm3, C. 16.8 dm3, D. 20.2 dm3

C (2013/2014, no, 5).

P4 + 5O2→ P4O10

No of moles of P oxidized = 

Molar mass = P4 = 31  4 = 124g/mol

Mass = 18.6

No of moles of P oxidized =  = 0.15mol

Therefore, 1mole of phosphorus requires 5moles of oxygen, we can now estimate what 0.15 mole of Phosphorus will require.

1mole of P = 5moles of O2 

0.15mole = X

X =  = 0.75 mole of O2

Since 1mole of oxygen (any gas) occupies 22.4dm3, then 0.75 mole will occupy

 =16.8dm3

Molecular Formular

Molecular Formular = (Empirical formular) n

n = number of each element present

Alkanoic acids form a homologous series with the empirical formula of CnH2n+1COOH. From the general formula, we have that 

(12 * n) + [1(2n +1)] + 12 +16 + 16 + 1 = 88 

12n+2n+1+45 = 88.

 14n + 46 = 88

14n = 88 - 46 =42 

n= 42 /14 = 3

We therefore obtain the molecular formula by substituting for n in the general formula. Le C3H7COOH
